content.description: This is a great slab boulder problem. Start on tight crimps. It gets more desperate from there. Go straight up till the jug.
content.location: Start about 6 feet to the right from the small cave.

content.description: This is a good intro to V2 ish climbing. The crux is the first move. It eases considerably after that.
content.location: It is just to the right of the cave on the north wall.

content.description: Go up the blankest part of the wall, and top out.
content.location: It is about 30 feet to the right of the cave on the north wall. Past a section of mossy slabs, you'll see a super clean piece of slab between the moss.

content.description: This is fun - it can almost be a roped climb. It is solid and mostly 5.6-5.7 climbing with one committing move. Start on left side of the ground block. Zag on the slanted crack to a good jug. Gain a jug in the groove, and top out. It's fun climbing, but the landing is bad, so don't fall!
content.protection: A pad and maybe a spotter - and be solid at this grade, as the landing is pretty bad.
content.location: To the left of the cave/fireplace, start on the left side of the block that forms the cave/fireplace.

content.description: This is a sit start to Chimney Stem. Start at the left side of the small cave with your left hand on a undercling/sidepull and your right hand on the block that is used as the left foot to start the original Chimney Stem. Work up in to the stem position, and then continue as for Chimney Stem. It feels a little less than a grade harder than the original.
content.location: This is at the far left of the North Wall in the small cave that appears to have been used for camp fires in the past.

content.description:
This is a great stem to a shallow crack problem. Stem start right at the little cave. You have good hands and feet to start, then go up and right until you get to a fantastic jug, and then top out.

 Yes, I am aware you can go left along the cracks avoiding the face, but this is way more fun and technical. Going left drops it down to V1-V2.
content.location: It starts at the cave that seems to have held a few drunken fire parties over the decades on the north side of the corridor.

content.description: Climb up the dirty, licheny crack with a baby birch tree growing out of it. Continue straight up easy moves to top out. Currently this is quite dirty but has good moderate movement, worth doing if you're in The Corridor.
content.protection: A pad and probably a spotter. It's tall, but the topout is casual.
content.location: On the north wall slab, to the right of "The Slapper" is a finger-size crack with a baby birch tree growing where it tapers out ~10 feet off the ground.

content.description: This is the North wall of the corridor formation in the Middlesex Fells.
